Chapter 3, Section 3: Distinguishing the Differences. Thus far, the characteristics of acquisition have been discussed. What are the characteristics of non-acquisition?
Verse:
Non-acquisition is pure and indeterminate, each of the past and future has three,
The three realms and the unattached three are accepted as the non-acquisition of the noble path,
Which is called the nature of ordinary beings. It is relinquished by acquiring the dharma or changing stages.
Discussion:
As for the distinction of natures, all non-acquisitions are exclusively categorized as the nature of undefiled indeterminate dharmas.
As for the distinction of time periods, each of the past and future has three kinds. That is to say, each of past dharmas and future dharmas has the non-acquisition of the three time periods.
If it is a present dharma, it only has the past and future non-acquisition.
There definitely is no present non-acquisition, because present dharmas do not coexist with non-acquisition.
Some say that present dharmas have no present non-acquisition, because their natures are mutually exclusive.

Present dharmas that can be accomplished are necessarily concomitant with acquisition and definitely have no non-acquisition. Dharmas that cannot be accomplished also have no non-acquisition. Therefore, present dharmas have no present non-acquisition.

As for the distinction of realms, dharmas belonging to the three realms and unconditioned dharmas each have three kinds of non-acquisition. That is to say, dharmas belonging to the desire realm have non-acquisition belonging to the three realms. The same is true for dharmas belonging to the form and formless realms and for unconditioned dharmas.
There definitely is no non-acquisition that is pure.
Why is this?
Because it is accepted that the non-acquisition of the noble path is called the nature of an ordinary person.
As the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:
What is the nature of an ordinary person?
It is the non-attainment of the dharmas of the noble ones.
Non-attainment is a synonym for non-acquisition. How can pure dharmas be called the nature of an ordinary person?
What dharmas of the noble ones are not attained called the nature of an ordinary person?
Is it the general non-attainment of all dharmas of the noble ones, or is it only the non-attainment of the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma of suffering?
Some say: It is the non-acquisition of all noble dharmas.
If so, wouldn't there be no non-ordinary beings, because there is no one who generally possesses all noble dharmas?

If there is non-acquisition that is not mixed with acquisition, that is the nature of an ordinary being. If it is mixed with acquisition, it is not the nature of an ordinary being. Therefore there is no error.
If so, the original treatise should speak of pure [non-acquisition].
No, because the meaning of the term is seen to exist.

Just as it is said that this class of beings eats water and eats wind. Although there is no pure [eating], it is also known that they purely eat water and wind, because it is not mixed with anything else.

Some say: It is the non-acquisition of the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing. However, after abandoning it, one does not again become an ordinary being, because one has already permanently destroyed that non-acquisition.
What is the reason for knowing that there is a separate real dharma called non-acquisition?
Because a scripture says there is possession and non-possession.
As a scripture says:
If one possesses six dharmas, one does not possess receptivity. The six dharmas are as in the sutra.
If you say that the state of the continuity of the eye and so on prior to the arising of the holy dharmas is called the nature of an ordinary man, then you are in conflict with the scriptures.
As the World Honored One said:
This is called the faith-follower entering the correct detachment from the stage of ordinary men and transcending the stage of ordinary men.
This stage of ordinary men is precisely the nature of an ordinary man.
Why do we know this?
Because it is like obtaining and abandoning.

Just as one is said to enter because one obtains a different dharma, one is said to transcend because one abandons a different dharma. At that time, one cannot be said to abandon even a small part of the dharmas such as the eye that one has already obtained, just as one cannot be said to obtain the holy dharmas that one has not yet obtained. Therefore, one cannot say that the continuity of the eye and so on prior to the arising of the holy dharmas is the nature of an ordinary man. Therefore, the principle is certain that there is a separate dharma that only ordinary men have, that pervades all ordinary men, and that conflicts with the attainment of the holy path, and it is called the nature of an ordinary man.
Isn't it just like saying that the holy dharmas themselves are the holy nature, and because one accomplishes this nature one is called a holy one;
Thus, the nature of ordinary beings should be the dharmas of ordinary beings, because one is called an ordinary being because one possesses this nature.
This example is not correct, because only noble ones have the dharmas of noble ones, so the dharmas of noble ones can be called the nature of noble ones.
But the dharmas of ordinary beings are also possessed by noble ones, so how can they be established as the nature of ordinary beings?
If the dharmas of ordinary beings are only produced by ordinary beings and are universal in the state of ordinary beings, then they can be the nature of ordinary beings.

But the evil destinies, the unconscious state, and the northern continent of Kuru are not universal to ordinary beings. Other things such as the faculty of life are universal to ordinary beings, but noble ones also possess them.
The subsidiary discussion is now complete. We should now consider when one abandons the non-acquisition of a dharma.
When one acquires a dharma, or when one changes to a different stage, one abandons the non-acquisition.
Just as the non-acquisition of the dharmas of noble ones is called the nature of ordinary beings, when one acquires the dharmas of noble ones, one abandons the non-acquisition of the three realms.

When one abides in the first pure mind, from the cognition of the factors of suffering, and so on, up to abiding in the vajra-like samÄdhi, the non-possession of the arhat is relinquished as appropriate upon obtaining this dharma.
In this way, up to the time when one attains the fruit of arhatship, the non-possession of the arhat who is liberated at the proper time is relinquished upon obtaining this dharma.
The non-possession of other dharmas should be considered in the same way.
Moreover, how is this non-possession called relinquishment?
When the possession of non-possession is severed and the non-possession of non-possession arises, this is called relinquishing non-possession.

Although possession and non-possession each have other [possessions and non-possessions], possession and non-possession are not endless. By the power of possession, the fundamental dharma and the possession of possession are accomplished. The power of the possession of possession accomplishes the possession of the dharma. How can it be endless?
Non-possession should also be considered in the same way.
The non-possession of non-possession definitely does not arise together.
Also, when one is born in a higher stage from a lower stage, the non-acquisition of the lower stage is completely abandoned.
When one is born in a lower stage from a higher stage, it should be understood in the same way. Because the power of the support causes the non-acquisition to change.
Thus the characteristics of acquisition and non-acquisition have been explained.
What is homogeneity?
Verse:
Homogeneity is the equality of sentient beings.
Treatise:
There is a separate real entity called homogeneity. It refers to the mutual similarity of sentient beings. The Abhidharma-Å›Ästra calls it the common characteristic.
The mutual similarity in form, faculties, activities, food, etc. of sentient beings born in the same realm and the mutual similarity in desires of sentient beings is called the common characteristic.
Just as the fresh and pure color is caused by karma, mind, and the four great elements, therefore form, etc. are not only caused by karma.
It is seen that form is the result of karma that attracts mutual similarity, because faculties, activities, food, etc. have differences.
If you say that the difference is due to the difference in the full complement of karma, this is not reasonable.
Or, the form of the body is produced only by the similar projecting karma, because the commonality of the aggregates has differences. Therefore, the differences in function, etc.
If the form of the body, etc. were only the result of karma, then the matter of function, etc. as desired, whether abandoned or undertaken, would not exist.
In this case, the form of the body, function, and desires are mutually similar, and therefore called commonality. This is the meaning of cause.
There is a separate real entity that is the common cause of this, and therefore it is called commonality.
The World-Honored One only speaks of this commonality in terms of sentient beings, not in terms of grass, trees, etc.
Therefore, a sutra says:
This is the commonality of the gods, this is the commonality of humans, and so on at length.
Therefore, the meaning of the existence of commonality is established. It is not only because of the mutual similarity in form and color.
There are innumerable kinds of commonality of sentient beings, distinguished by realm, destination, rebirth, body, etc.
There is also a dharma homogeneity, which refers to the aggregates, sense bases, and elements. It is the basis of the homogeneity of the multitude, and non-sentient beings do not have it.
The homogeneity of ordinary beings is abandoned when one enters the stage of separation from desire.
The homogeneity of sentient beings is abandoned when one enters nirvana.
Isn't the nature of ordinary beings the homogeneity of ordinary beings?
This is not so, because their functions are different.
The cause of mutual similarity in form, function, and desires is called homogeneity.
If it is contrary to the attainment of the noble path, it is the cause of being an ordinary being, and is called the nature of being an ordinary being.
When one enters the stage of separation from desire, one abandons and attains homogeneity, but abandons the nature of being an ordinary being without attaining it.
Homogeneity is not form. How do we know this?
Because there is a function that produces it, but no separate class of things. We know it exists because we see its effects.
Just as we know there were previously created karmas from seeing the effects obtained from present karmas.
Also, because contemplatives directly experience and know it.
Why not admit that there is a common lot of insentient things?
One should not be so critical, because it would be a mistake to go too far.
You also admit that there are destinies of humans and gods and births as embryos and eggs, etc., why not also admit that there are destinies of mango trees, etc., and births as mung beans, etc.?
Moreover, the World-Honored Buddha never said so.
One should only consider why the World-Honored One only speaks of the common lot of sentient beings, not of grasses, etc.
Moreover, how do you know that such a common lot is an actual real entity?
I understand it like this: because grasses, etc., have no mutual activity or desire to resemble each other, a separate common lot is not spoken of in regard to them.
Moreover, grasses, etc., only arise due to sentient beings, therefore the common lot is only spoken of in regard to sentient beings.
Moreover, this dharma arises due to past karma and present effort, but in those grasses, etc., both are absent, therefore there is no common lot.
This very fact proves that there is an actual real entity.
Moreover, although images such as wood, cloth, lacquer, carving, painting, etc., and their true forms have color and shape that are similar to each other, it is said that they are real.

For this reason, it is not only by seeing their similarity that one says they are real. One must have a real expression with regard to similar differentiated things. Therefore, one should know that there is this differentiated dharma that is real. This real expression arises from this dharma.
Also, because it was said before.
What was said before?
It was said that seeing the body and form is the result drawn by karma. Because the functions of the faculties and food and drink, etc., are differentiated.
How is it that with regard to those different from each other by the various kinds of similarity, without further kinds of similarity, there arises the cognition and designation of non-difference?

Because the various kinds of similarity are the nature of the cause of similar events, they are the cause for the cognition and designation of similarity with each other. Just as the eyes, ears, etc., become the nature of form only by being made from the great elements. Although the great elements do not have other great elements to make them, the nature of form is accomplished.
This would then manifest as the general and specific characteristics grasped at by the SÄá¹ƒkhyas.
If the SÄá¹ƒkhyas grasp at these two characteristics, their substance is not one, they are momentary and impermanent, they have no basis, and they are mutually distinct.

What are the characteristics of the first attainment of non-perception?
Verse:
Thus, the attainment of non-perception, in the subsequent meditative absorption, seeks liberation,
is wholesome, only conducive to the experience of rebirth, not noble, and attained for one lifetime.
Commentary:
As previously explained, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of non-perception.
Similarly, there is another separate dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of non-perception.

The phrase thus only shows that this meditative absorption causes the cessation of mind and mental factors to be the same as the attainment of non-perception. Because it is accomplished or perfectly accomplished, it is called meditative absorption.
Some other masters say:
It is called meditative absorption because it causes the mind to function equally in accordance with principle, because it causes the mind and the four great elements to function equally.

The attainment of non-perception is either the meditative absorption of non-perception or the non-perception attained through meditative absorption, because this meditative absorption arises from the aversion and destruction of conceptualization.
Ordinary beings are unable to avert and destroy feelings, because they enter meditative absorption while indulging in feelings.
In what stage is this samÄdhi?
It is in the fourth dhyÄna, not in other stages.
This should not be said.
Why?
This samÄdhi can induce the retribution of non-perception.
It has already been said that non-perception exists in the heaven of vast fruit. It will be said that vast fruit is in the fourth dhyÄna. How can it be cultivated in other stages?
This criticism is unreasonable, because it has never been said. It has never been said that the samÄdhi of non-perception is the cause of non-perception.
Isn't it said in the previous verse that non-perception is retribution, and in the explanation of that it is said to be the fruit of the samÄdhi of non-perception?
This is also unreasonable, because there has never been a verse that says this. Now it becomes established.
Why is this samÄdhi called the samÄdhi of ordinary beings?
Because it is cultivated in order to seek liberation.
They take non-perception to be true liberation, and take the samÄdhi of non-perception to be the path of departure. In order to realize non-perception, they cultivate this samÄdhi.
All sages do not grasp contaminated states as true liberation or true deliverance, therefore this concentration is called the concentration of ordinary beings.
Previously it was said that the state of non-perception is retribution, so it is categorized as indeterminate and does not need to be discussed separately.
Now, the state of non-perception is entirely wholesome. Isn't it categorized as wholesome because it is the cause of retribution? It does not need to be discussed separately.
This [state of non-perception] is the cause that can attract the five aggregates of retribution among the gods of non-perception.
No, because it is not yet mentioned in the verse.
Moreover, who can deny that it is defiled or indeterminate?
If so, it should be said here that it is purely wholesome.

No, because the meaning of seeing is established by separating from words. This should be explained according to the previous explanation of the nature of ordinary beings, or it is already made clear that it is not the other [two natures] by simply saying wholesome.
Since this concentration is the nature of the cause of retribution, to which feeling does it correspond?
It only corresponds to the feeling of birth, not to the feelings of the present, the future, or the indeterminate.
One group of teachers definitely holds this view, which is in accord with the experience of rebirth and indeterminate experience.
Why is this?
One who has attained this concentration may also be able to enter the certainty of perfection.
Once entered, this concentration will definitely not arise again.
Because it is said that the name of the concentration of non-discrimination is the concentration of ordinary beings based on its present activity,
not based on its possession.

Moreover, it is admitted that this concentration is common to both ordinary beings and those outside the Dharma, and is attained by ordinary beings, not by saints. This is because the saints, seeing this concentration as a deep pit, do not delight in entering it.

The phrase seeking liberation has already been stated in the verse, which clearly shows that this concentration belongs only to ordinary beings. To say again that it is not of the saints would be useless.
When it is first attained, how many moments are attained?
In all states, like the precepts of individual liberation, it is attained separately in each moment, because it has not been attained before.

In the first moment, it is not attained in the past, because there is no mind. It is not cultivated in the future, therefore, when first attained, it is only attained in one moment, namely, the present.

The second moment and subsequent moments, up to the time of emerging, also constitute the past. After emerging, up to the time of relinquishment, it only constitutes the past. Like the divine eye and ear, there is no cultivation of the future. It is only attained through added effort, not through detachment.
Next, what is the characteristic of the attainment of cessation?
The verse says:
The attainment of cessation is also like this. It is for the sake of tranquil abiding in the summit of existence.
It is wholesome, with two feelings, and is not definite. The noble ones attain it through added effort.
The Buddha attains it without the previous thirty-four moments.
The treatise says:
The attainment of cessation is also like this, as with the attainment of non-perception.

That is to say, for one who has already abandoned craving for the third meditative absorption, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of non-perception.
Similarly, for one who has already abandoned craving for the sphere of nothingness, there is a dharma that can cause the cessation of mind and mental factors, called the attainment of cessation.

The difference between these two samÄdhis is that the former, the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization, is for the sake of liberation and is a disgust with conceptualization. It is realized by making the thought of liberation precede it.
The latter, the samÄdhi of cessation, is for the sake of seeking a tranquil abiding and is a disgust with the agitation of the mind. It is realized by making the thought of cessation precede it.

The former, the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization, is in the final stage of the realm of form, while the latter, the samÄdhi of cessation, is in the final stage of the formless realm. The body that one receives by being born in the stage of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization is the most superior of all bodies, being attracted by the most superior of all actions.
It is called the summit of existence, or it is called the summit of existence because it is the limit of existence, just as the limit of a tree is called the top of the tree.
Why is it that this samÄdhi exists only in this stage and not in lower stages?
Because one can only attain this superior liberation by being disgusted with all minds and by temporarily cutting off the final mind.
That is to say, this liberation is established on the basis of two conditions:
first, because one is disgusted with all minds, and second, because the final mind is temporarily cut off.
If one has this samÄdhi in a lower stage, he does not detest all kinds of minds, because he has not yet detested the minds of the higher stages.
It is also not called the cessation of the ultimate mind, because the minds of the higher stages have not yet been eliminated.
It should be called the detesting of a small part of the mind, and it should also be called the cessation of the middle mind.
Of the three natures, the former and this samÄdhi are both good, not defiled or indeterminate.
This is because no holy person detests and fears the agitation of the mind and takes the defiled or indeterminate as a tranquil abode.

The former samÄdhi of nonconceptualization can conform to the production of retribution and indeterminate retribution. Now the samÄdhi of cessation conforms to the production of retribution in the next life and indeterminate retribution, that is, in regard to the maturation of retribution, it conforms to the production of retribution in the next life or the production of retribution in the present life, or it conforms to indeterminate retribution or to no retribution at all. Ordinary beings are unable to generate the state of cessation, because they have not yet eliminated the obstacle to the generation of the state of cessation that exists in their own stage, and they are unable to transcend the views that are to be eliminated during the path of seeing in the summit of existence.
Ordinary beings are unable to transcend the views that are to be eliminated during the path of seeing in the summit of existence, and therefore only noble ones attain the state of cessation.
Do all noble ones attain the state of cessation when they attain the summit of existence?
It should be said that they do not attain it, because this state is not attained through the elimination of passion.
Through what is it attained?
It is attained through added effort, because it is realized only through added effort.
When the state of nondiscernment is first realized, only the present state is attained, and the past state is not attained.
One does not cultivate the future state, because one is able to cultivate it only through the power of thought.
In the second moment and thereafter, until one abandons it, one also realizes the past state.
Is the state of cessation also attained through added effort by the World Honored One?
No, it is not so.

They are obtained at the time of becoming a Buddha. They say that the World Honored One obtains them at the time of the knowledge of extinction.

Because when the bodhisattva abides in the vajra-like samÄdhi, it is called obtaining the knowledge of extinction. When the essence is obtained, it is called obtained.

At the time of becoming a Buddha, it should be said that the knowledge of extinction appears without exertion. When the desire and pleasure to appear temporarily arises, all the perfect virtues arise according to the desire and pleasure.
How can it be said that the Buddha obtains the concentration of extinction at the time of the knowledge of extinction?

Because at the time of the bodhisattva, all afflictions and defilements are permanently severed, causing the virtues in the Buddha's body to be obtained. Therefore it is said that all the virtues of the TathÄgata are obtained through the severance of defilements.
Therefore what they say also has faults.

Even though it has been said that the two samÄdhis have many similarities and differences, there are still similarities and differences among them.
A verse says:
The two concentrations rely on desire and form, and the concentration of cessation first arose in the human realm.
The treatise says:
The two concentrations refer to the concentration of non-perception and the concentration of cessation. Both can manifest in the desire realm and form realm.
However, some say that one enters the concentration of non-perception only in the lower three meditations, not in the fourth, lest the cause be too close to the effect.
Some say that one can also enter the concentration of non-perception in the fourth meditation, except for the heaven of non-perception, because one is born in that heaven and experiences its effects.

One enters the concentration of non-perception only in the desire realm, not in the form realm.
This contradicts the treatise, which states:
There is form existence, but this existence is not the five aggregates.

It refers to sentient beings in the form realm, or those born in the heavens of perception, abiding in minds of different types, either entering the concentration of non-perception, or entering the concentration of cessation, or being born in the heaven of non-perception.
Having already entered the state of non-perception, this is called the existence of form, but this existence is not the five aggregates.
Based on this evidence, we know that these two concentrations both arise in dependence on the desire realm and form realm. This is called their common characteristic.

As for their different characteristics, the concentration of non-perception can first arise in both the desire realm and form realm, but the concentration of cessation can only first arise in the human realm.
The concentration of cessation can only first be cultivated and attained in the human realm. It only exists in the human realm.

Now we must consider why, when all mind and mental activities are generally extinguished in the samÄdhi of cessation, it is said that only feeling and conceptualization are extinguished?

Treatise:
The essence of the faculty of life is the same as life.
Therefore, the Abhidharma treatise says:
What is the faculty of life?
It refers to the life of the three realms.
Although the names differ, the essence is not yet clear. It should be further explained.
What dharma is called life?
It refers to a separate dharma that can support warmth and consciousness, which is called life.

Life, warmth, and consciousness, when these three dharmas leave the body,
The abandoned body lies still, like a piece of wood without thought or perception.
If so, what dharma can support this life?
I say that this life can support karma, because it is exclusively the result of karma ripening, and it always evolves throughout one's life.
Heat is not a result of retribution that is definitely produced by action.

Consciousness is not either of the two, because although it always evolves in a place that is definitely produced by action, it is not definitely a result of retribution produced by action. Therefore it cannot be said that consciousness is held by action.
Therefore it is said that life holds heat and consciousness, and they are not results of retribution produced by action.

In the evolution of consciousness, action has a certain power to hold it, because in the same class of existence, consciousness that is born of retribution is interrupted and then continues, and it is held only by the power of life.
How do we know that life holds heat?
Because there is heat only when there is life. We see that there is life even when there is no heat. Therefore we know that the substance of life is not held by heat.
Consequently, we know that there is a real entity apart from heat, whose power holds the heat and consciousness of a sentient being, and it is called life, which is the faculty of life.
Thus the faculty of life does not only depend on the body, because it exists even in the formless realm.
It does not only depend on mind, because it exists even when there is no mind.
If this is so, then on what does it depend?
The common characteristics of sentient beings are also like this, based on past karma and the present common characteristics.
What is the difference between life force and life duration?
Life force refers to the life of conditioned dharmas, while life duration refers to the life of unconditioned dharmas.
Some say:

Some also say:
The fruit of spiritual powers is called life force, while the fruit of past karma is called life duration.
Some also say: That which arises from the predominance of wisdom is called life force, while that which arises from the predominance of ignorance is called life duration.
Some also say: That which is obtained by the continuum of one free from greed is called life force, while that which is obtained by the continuum of one with greed is called life duration.
This is the difference between life force and life duration.

What are the characteristics?

What are the four?
The verse says:

The treatise says:

These four kinds are the characteristics of conditioned phenomena, because they manifest their nature. Therefore, they are called characteristics. Based on this, there are various types of conditioned phenomena.
Among them, arising refers to a separate dharma that is the supreme cause without obstruction in the state of arising of conditioned phenomena. Because it can attract and bring about their arising.
That which can attract and bring about means that when they arise, this dharma can be their supreme condition.

Although the arising of conditioned phenomena can all be called arising, this term arising is established only based on the supreme cause without obstruction in the state of arising of conditioned phenomena. Because conditioned phenomena arise due to the power of causes and conditions that arise before, arise simultaneously, are of the same type, or are of different types, this will be extensively explained in the chapter on causes and effects.

Among similar and dissimilar conditions in previous lives, similar conditions are stronger because they arise following them. Within the condition of simultaneous arising, there are no similar conditions. Among dissimilar conditions, there are those that are particularly superior. For example, in the arising of eye consciousness conditioned by eye and form, the eye is said to be the cause and form is said to be the condition.

Although following the arising of one eye consciousness, another eye consciousness does not arise, yet the arising of eye consciousness follows the eye, not form. Because it is the proximate condition, it is said to be the cause.
The various dharmas of one fruit simultaneously arising with eye consciousness assist the power of consciousness, which is superior to the eye.

Moreover, among the dharmas of one fruit that arise together, there are those that have the power of mutual arising that is particularly superior. For example, wind assists the power of fire, causing it to blaze. Because this is well established in the world,

it is directly perceived that wind in a different aggregate is particularly conducive to fire. Therefore, it can be inferred that in the same aggregate, it is necessarily so. Therefore, among the conditions of simultaneous arising, those whose power of arising is superior are unilaterally established as the name of arising.
The function of this arising is most evident in the initial moment of arising of the various attainments of the uncontaminated.
Since we see that it exists in this place, we can infer that it also exists in other places.

Dharmas of abiding are separate dharmas that cause conditioned forces that have already been produced and have not yet been destroyed to lead to their own fruits without obstruction, and are the superior causes.
Just as the production of conditioned forces must depend on a separate dharma as a superior cause that assists in leading to the fruit, so too must it depend on a separate dharma as a cause.

The SarvÄstivÄdins maintain that conditioned forces that temporarily exist as real entities in dependence on a multitude of causes and conditions are called present, and they also say that they have abiding. At that time, conditioned forces lead to their own fruits.
Also, they are established as activity-real nature in this.

Conditioned forces temporarily abide.
Also, it is said that form has birth, abiding, and time.
This cannot be said to refer to a series, because even in a single moment it is also of the nature of suffering, and a series is necessarily formed by moments.

The characteristics of conditioned dharmas are established on the basis of a succession of prior and subsequent moments in a series. This is not established by reason, and therefore there must be a separate dharma that is the proximate cause that is not an obstacle to the activity of projecting results of the various conditioned forces. The Abhidharma masters say that this is duration.

Dissimilarity is a separate dharma that is the cause of the succession of similar conditioned forces, one after another. It cannot be that there is no cause for dissimilarity, and that there is naturally dissimilarity. The succession of similar moments of consciousness cannot be without a cause for transformation, because this is not established by reason.

The succession of such things as feeling in the formless realm is moment by moment transformation. This function is most evident, and we see that the formless realm has a superior power of dissimilarity, and by inference we should understand that the other realms also have it.
Cessation is a separate dharma that is the cause of the proximate cessation of the various conditioned forces. It is the superior cause that is not an obstacle to cessation.

One cannot maintain that the nature of cessation as a characteristic of the unconditioned is not established by reason, because it arises from conditions. It is also not correct to say that it has arising and cessation.

If the characteristics of conditioned dharmas have four different substances, why does the scripture speak only of three?
The scripture does not speak of duration in order to reveal the differences of good and evil qualities of conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.

Other scriptures say that the activities of dharmas have birth and cessation, not different characteristics. This is also the case with the characteristics of conditioned dharmas.
Even though there are four characteristics, in accordance with the needs of those to be taught, duration is hidden and only three are spoken of, and there is no error.
Or, in this scripture, duration is already secretly mentioned, because there is no word only.

The meaning of abiding and change in this scripture does not show that abiding is change, but only shows that conditioned dharmas have arising, ending, abiding, and change. The arising of arising, etc., refers to the four secondary characteristics, which are the arising of arising up to the cessation of cessation.
The conditioned dharmas are conditioned by the four fundamental characteristics, and the fundamental characteristics are conditioned by the four secondary characteristics.

As for the statement that the arising of the class [of conditioned dharmas] can also be known, it should be explained according to reason.

Even for unconditioned dharmas, the fundamental characteristics such as birth cannot be known, let alone the secondary characteristics such as birth-birth that can be obtained.
If it were not so, it should only be said that arising, etc., can be known, and it should not be said that even.
Moreover, the Blessed One said in the sutra that the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas] have characteristics again.
The sutra says that form has arising and cessation, and this should also be known to have arising and cessation, and so on at length.
For this reason, it is known that characteristics have characteristics again.
If it were so, then each fundamental characteristic, like the dharma it characterizes, should have four kinds of secondary characteristics.
Moreover, each of these is fourfold, and so on, ad infinitum. There is no fault of infinite regress.

The four fundamental characteristics and the four secondary characteristics have different powers with regard to the eight and one, respectively. The power of the fundamental characteristics is called their power.
That is, the four fundamental characteristics each have a function with regard to eight dharmas, and the four secondary characteristics each have a function with regard to one dharma.
